channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Immigration Crackdown Creates Fault Lines Among Baptists
item.description: An increasingly loud contingent supports the Trump administration’s efforts to deport illegal immigrants.

item.title: Trump Takes America’s ‘Imperial Presidency’ to a New Level
item.description: In his first year back in the White House, President Trump has greatly expanded executive power while embracing the trappings of royalty in ways not s...

item.title: Freed From a Belarus Prison, a Nobel Peace Laureate Experiences ‘Oxygen Intoxication’
item.description: Ales Bialiatski, who shared the Nobel in 2022, described long hours of backbreaking work and stints in solitary confinement.

item.title: A Walmart employee nearly doubled her pay after entering its pipeline for skilled tradespeople. ‘I was able to move out of my parents’ house’
item.description: “I have my own apartment. I was able to get a car, and and I’m able to give more to my 401(k).”

item.title: Elon Musk adds to his $679 billion fortune after Delaware court reverses its earlier decision and awards him a $55 billion Tesla pay package
item.description: In 2024, Chancellor Kathaleen St. Jude McCormick rescinded the compensation in a case brought by a disgruntled Tesla shareholder.

item.title: When Something Goes Wrong With Your Flight, These People Take Charge
item.description: Inside a tornado-hardened office in Texas, 1,700 American Airlines employees manage the carrier’s operations, responding to bad weather, plane trouble...

item.title: U.S. forces stop second tanker off the coast of Venezuela after Trump vows oil ‘blockade’
item.description: A crude oil tanker flying under the flag of Panama operating under the Centuries was recently spotted near the Venezuelan coast.

item.title: Meet a 55-year-old automotive technician in Arkansas who didn’t care if his kids went to college: ‘There are options’
item.description: Clint Crawford has a message for parents who are concerned about the shortage of white-collar entry-level work: open their minds to the possibility of...

item.title: Georgia regulators approve 50% power capacity boost, betting that massive AI data center demand will eventually materialize
item.description: "If in 10 years, the AI bubble bursts or the data centers move to a cheaper state, then the roommate moves out, but the mortgage doesn’t go away.”

item.title: Sydney Shooting Suspects Met Muslim Leaders in Philippines, Officials Say
item.description: Intelligence authorities in the Philippines say the father and son apparently slipped out of Davao City during their monthlong stay, but details remai...

item.title: When Something Goes Wrong With Your Flight, These People Take Charge
item.description: Inside a tornado-hardened office in Texas, 1,700 American Airlines employees manage the carrier’s operations, responding to bad weather, plane trouble...

item.title: Long Before Bondi Massacre, Australian Jews Lived With a Sense of Peril
item.description: Armed guards, bollards and secretive precautions became part of life amid antisemitic attacks and blurred lines between anger at Israel and hatred of ...

item.title: 9 Killed in Mass Shooting at Tavern in South Africa
item.description: Around a dozen gunmen opened fire at random at bar patrons, the police said. A manhunt for the unknown assailants was underway.

item.title: Michele Singer Reiner: A Life Rooted in Activism and Listening to Others
item.description: Michele Singer Reiner was the guiding force in the lives of her family, stressing the need to help and respect one another.

item.title: Freed From a Belarus Prison, a Nobel Peace Laureate Experiences ‘Oxygen Intoxication’
item.description: Ales Bialiatski, who shared the Nobel in 2022, described long hours of backbreaking work and stints in solitary confinement.
